column8: In this course weïŠre dealing with at most a dozen of lines or so in each exercise and using pre-cooked templates on the assignments. Real life is quite different; we will face hundreds of lines w/o helping clues or templates. It will be us on our own. So, getting acquainted with IDLE or any other Python editor for testing and running programs, finding syntax errors, etc., in a development environment is a must. Pseudocodes and pen and paper are valuable tools indeed, but you are supposed to deliver a running, debugged and well tested program to your clients. One thing is knowing how a car engine works, another different one is designing such an engine that works. ï_So,If, on the other hand, you have been avoiding using IDLE, and you're struggling with the exercises (OR NOT), then you aren't learning as much as you should.

column2: Lectures / Week 1 / Python as a Calculator
column8: When it really comes down to it, you won't be asking yourself "Which language is the best?" Instead you'll be asking "Which language is the best for the problem at hand?"Some languages are better than others at certain things. C++ falls down when you're trying to make something portable between OS, whereas Python and Java don't worry as much. Although in terms of speed they fall well short of C++. And say you're looking to do some web stuff, in that case things like PHP become your best friend.The best advice you can be given is not to peg yourself to a language, you'll enjoy some more than others, and there'll be some that you downright hate (Visual Basic, for example :D ) But you don't use a spanner to hammer in a nail, you'll come to points where another language will be the best option and will save you a lot of heartache.Most importantly, don't think of this as learning to program in Python, instead think that you are learning to program. Really what you want to get out of this is an idea of what you can do and what the basic structures of Procedural/OO Programming are. (Most of the time learning your second or third language will be based off saying "I could do this in <language x>, how can it be done in <language y>?"), once you know what's possible, you have a better idea of what to type into google to make it so in that new language.

I use Homebrew to install stuff like Python, it's a nifty little command line tool that gives you access to a lot of applications that will make your life easier. LINK To get python3 running:1. Download Homebrew by opening a terminal and copying this command into the prompt.ruby -e "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.github.com/mxcl/homebrew/go)"2. Run these two commands, again copy and paste into your terminal and press enterbrew update; brew doctorThese two ensure that you're getting the latest versions of anything you install using homebrew, doctor will also let you know if there's anything wrong with your installation.3. Run the command to install python3brew install python34. That's it, you now have a command line version of python3 installed and running,To run Python3 open your terminal and type in 'python3', if you want to use IDLE, than 'idle3' won't steer you wrong.

Parameters are used to define what is given to a function.def add(X, Y):    return X + YIn this case, X and Y are the parameters. When defining 'add', you are telling python that every time add is called the user will include two arguments.Somewhere in your code, you'll call add, say 'add(1,2)' or even 'add(somevariable, someothervariable)'In this case 1 and 2, or somevariable and someothervariable are arguments. They are the items that fullfill the parameters.The way I think about it is this:Think of Parameters when you're defining a function.Parameters are the rules of what must be included in the function call, whenever you call a function you must have as many arguments as you have parameters.Arguments are used when you're calling/invoking a function.Arguments are what is passed a function, they hold the information you want the function to use.To be honest, I've never seen anwhere else where the distinction between parameters and arguments has been so stressed. However, the easiest way I can think of to differentiate the two is this.Parameters = Defining a functionArguments = Calling/Invoking a function

column2: Lectures / Week 2 / Input/Output and str Formatting
column8: Every now and then you want to return something prematurely. For example, consider if you want to do a bunch of stuff, and then only continue if a certain condition is met:def stop_if_false(x, check):    x = x + 3    if check == false:        return x    x = x / 2    return xIn the above case, if check is false, then x = x / 2 won't take place. If it is true, then x = x /2 will be evaluated.At the moment we aren't using conditionals, but knowing that return drops us out of the current function will be quite important later.

column8: I think something that is quite confusing about this is what the python interpreter actually doing with a returned value.>>> def average(num1, num2):	return (num1 + num2) / 2>>> average(1, 2)1.5>>> The interpreter does something here that you wouldn't see in a script. If you make yourself a .py file and put the definition and the function call in it so...def average(num1, num2):    return (num1 + num2) / 2average(1, 2)Now save and run that module, you'll notice that no output is displayed.This is because when you return a value from a function, the python interpreter does something different when you return from a function and have nothing for that value to be placed in and prints the result on the screen, When using the interpreter, calling a function without placing the return value anywhere is like calling>>> tmp = average(1,2)>>> print(tmp)Perhaps it's Python trying to be helpful.

column8: Exactly my point, When the two are arguing over whether the bridge should be blue or red, as a driver I don't really care about the colour. As long as the bridge is functional and I drive on one side and can drive off correctly on the other. Cosmetics like this are really irrelevant, in some situations you will find that one is better than the other in terms of processing required but most of the time it's really just a matter of personal preference.

I've found in most cases to this point, you'll find that the case is reallydef doSomething(x, canIDoIt):    if not canIDoIt:        return -1    else:        #Do some stuff with x    return xWhich won't really take any more processing time than sayingdef doSomething(x, canIDoIt):       res = -1    if canIDoIt:       res = x       # Do whatever with res    return res

If you run the visualiser tool that is being used so much in this course (With good reason, it's a beautiful bit of software.)You'll see that:def isTempRight(temp)    if temp == 22.5:
        return True
    return FalseRunning isTempRight(22.5), the first thing that happens is temp == 22.5 or 22.5 == 22.5 is evaluated. This is true. So the body of the if statement is executed. return True is called, we exit the function, and tell the calling function that the result was true. Running isTempRight(30), this time we try 30 == 22.5. This is not true, so the body of the if statement is skipped, we move straight down to return False. So we exit the function and tell the caller that the result was false.

column8: These things help if you draw truth tables.| M | B | C | M or B or C | T | T | T | T| T | T | F | T| T | F | F | T| F | T | T | T| F | F | T | T| F | T | F | T| T | F | T | T| F | F | F | FIf you remember, as long as at least one of the statements used in an or is true, then the or results in being true. So the only way M or B or C would be false, is if Little Johnny was a bit thick and failed Math, Bio and CS.Thinking about this on the other side, all we know is that M or B or C came up true, so what can we say without a shadow of a doubt?We can't say that Little Johnny passed all exams, the that would only work if we were using M and B and C.As we know that the result is true when at least one result was a pass, then we can say that Little Johnny passed at least one exam

column8: Recursion. It's beautiful and brutal all at once.Think about it in terms of the Fibonacci sequence function.We know that each number in the Fibonacci sequence is calculated by adding the previous two numbers together. So 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8...Recursion works by having a base case (In this case, fib(0) = 0 and fib(1)) and then having a well defined way to work backwards from any case to our base case.Say we call fib(3), what we're expecting to happen is this...fib(3), 3 != 1 and 3 != 0, so return the result of fib(2)+ fib(1)     fib(2), 2 != 1 and 2 != 0, so return the result of fib(1) +  fib(0)         fib(1) returns 1         Fib(0) returns 0     fib(2) = fib(1) + fib(0) = 1 + 0 = 1          fib(1) returns 1fib(3) = fib(2) + fib(1) = 1 + 1 = 2So the third number in the Fibonacci sequence is 2.A few things to watch out for:1. If your base case isn't right, or your working backwards isn't right, your program will crash.2. If you delve too deeply with recursion, you'll run out of memory and your program will fail.3. Usually if you can do something recursively, you can also do it iteratively (using a loop of some kind). iteratively usually ends up being a bit nicer on your memory.

column8: Another simple recursive function would be finding a character in a string. For example:def findChar(s, char):   if s == '':       return False   if s[0] == char       return True   return findChar(s[1:], char)I know, I know, we could just say return char in s, but this is an example.In this case we have two different base classes:1. The string is empty, we know the character is not here.2. The first character in the string is the one that we are looking for. The character is inside the string.So say we called findChar('Average', 'r'), if we work through how this would execute, we can build a table:Call # | Current String | Is the first character 'r'? | Next statement to execute1 | Average | No | findChar('verage', 'r')2 | verage | No | findChar('erage', 'r')3 | erage | No | findChar('rage', r)4 | erage | Yes | return True Or maybe weï_ try with findChar('Tim', u):Call # | Current String | Is the first character 'r'? | Next statement to execute1 | Tim | No | findChar('im', 'u')2 | im | No | findChar('m', 'u')3 | m | No | findChar('', u)4 | '' | No | return False As you can see, the way recursion works is we use what we do know (We know that if the string is empty then the character is not in the string, and we know that if the character we want is the first character in the string to search, than it does exist in the string) in order to solve our problem by breaking down to that level. In mathematics recursion is based off saying that if you can solve a problem p for p(0), and if you can solve a problem for p(1), then you can use this to solve any problem for p(n)In regards of what gets returned, remember when we were doing things like return 1 == 1, the 1 == 1 is evaluated before it is returned, so in the example of findChar('Average', 'r'):findChar('Average', 'r'):                   ^->     findChar('verage', 'r'):             |    ->     findChar('erage', 'r'):          |        ->     findChar('rage', 'r'): True! |In this way the last called function is worked through first and the value gets passed back up through the stack.Sorry for the long windedness, as a Prolog programmer I love recursion.

However, the dot operator is used to reference the object's methods and functions.As stated above, anything that involves an operator that isn't the dot operator is fair game, so you can do str * 5, str[5:6], str[4] and even str + str.Anything that involves str.<anything> is not allowed though.

column8: Programming in Python is just writing out a series of steps. If you know all the steps (Which you should when you're the one writing the steps), then you'll know what the output of a function will be.Tracing by hand is great for testing because you can keep a list in your head of where the program is at any given moment, what all of the values are, and what's going on.Say you have a function that when you give it the value 4, you expect it to return 16. If the function instead returns 12, you can work through the steps yourself and see where there might be a bug in your code.Personally, I'd rather trace things by hand than use a debugger in all but the most extreme of examples. But that's because I find most of the debuggers irritating and slow.

column8: As a point of interest, I ran some numbers. This is working off my own set of test cases, and my own assignment 2 file.Size of file: 2724 bytesNumber of test cases: 50Time taken on my computer: 25ms on average.Using these numbers, let's say that everyone that enrolled in the course is submitting their assignments, we'll use the worst case here, if they all submit at the same time then we would see 168.86 Mb of data needing to be downloaded to the server on the next poll of submitted assignments (65000*2724) This would also cause the amount of testing time to be around 25*65000 milliseconds, which actually ends up being around half an hour. This is quite a simple outlook, I haven't bothered considering a parallel running of the marking. I also don't include the time needed to output the results to the webpage.Consider that everyone is submitting once every 5-10 seconds, it's quite clear that without a decent sized gap between submissions would cause an almost constant load on the server.Moving down, let's consider if only the people who submitted something for assignment 1 managed to do so for assignment two. In the announcements this is listed as 3874. so...3874*2724 = 10552776, so closer to 10 MbAnd 25*3874 = 9685, which is just over a minute.I think the original delay was created to ensure that in the worst case the number of people submitting could be handled. Could this be throttled back now? Probably.Tim: Hitting your arguments with Mathematics, every Thursday.

column8: Remember that you can have lists inside lists. These are commonly called multidimensional lists.So say a looks like this:a = ['a', ['b', 'c'], 'd']a[1] is equal to the second item in the top level list, which is ['b', 'c'], since this is a list, we can also access it's items using the same square bracket notationa[1][0] notates that you want the 0th index of the list that is stored at the 1st index of list a. In this case, a[1][0] == 'b'In question 10, a[1][0] would cause an error, because you're trying to treat an int as a list, and this isn't allowed.

column8: No one is ever going to say to you "I wish you hadn't documented that". However, there are going to be times when they'll say "Did you need that much documentation?"I'd say keep the docstrings, they are great for getting a quick look at what's happening in your code.Keep comments that are unnecessary to a minimum, for parts of it you're going to find that your code is pretty self explanatory, and if not you can rewrite the layout/change some variable names to help with this.On the topic of unit tests, perhaps put them in a separate file? That way they won't get in the way of the actual code.

I'm not sure I understand here, but if you have the file set up like this:IDtNametMarkstRank1tTomt76t32tDickt95t23tHarryt97t1Remember that each line is just a string, so you can use a function to split the line on tabs to create a list that holds [1, 'Tom', 76, 3]... And so on. At this point you can access name using List[1].If you're looking for being able to say line[Name], or something to that tune. Look up python's dictionaries, they allow you to create lists that have keys.So you'd be able to do things like have a list of dictionaries and say results[1]['Name'] == 'Dick'I won't tell you how to do this, because it's 1am, I've got work tomorrow, and I'm too tired to hack together some code, but your code would look something like this:readline list of headingssplit headers up to get each header ['ID', 'Name', 'Marks', 'Rank']For each record of file:   Get next line   Divide up string in sections   Build dictionary ['ID'=1, 'Name'='Tom', 'Marks'=76, 'Rank'=3]   Add this to a list of dictionariesOnce you have this list of dictionaries built up, you can access a record using the index of the record, and then use the label to get the exact data you want.Happy coding, if you have any questions ask and I'll try to answer in the morning. :)Link to dictionaries documentation: http://docs.python.org/3.2/tutorial/datastructures.html

column8: The most important step when learning something new is to NOT give up! So keep trying until you make it because you will get it as long as you try! But you are on the right track, I can see that on your code!Now on to your problem. You need to study the function design recipe (video 3 - 5) in order to understand what each part of the function is supposed to do. The "return" - statement or the Body as it's really called is supposed to execute your code.ï_So if you are making a smoothie, you might have already put all the ingredients in the mixer but you haven't pressed the button that will mix your smoothie together and that will be the final step before you have a ready to drink beverage.The same idea applies to the function design recipe, all the other lines are your ingredients, your tools which you use the function for but the return is what mixes all those ingredients into what will then become the final product.So think of what you want with your code. You want to know how many seconds different are the two times, right? How do you, outside of Python, in real life, calculate the difference between two things? Just like you have started to do, you subtract them with each other in order to get the difference.The problem with your code is the seconds_difference in that line. seconds_difference is a function and you don't need to return the actual function, you need to return the value of that function. So what is the value? time_1 and time_2. And what was it again we needed to do? calculate the difference between time_1 and time_2. So in other words, you need to take out seconds_difference from the body(return) and see what happens!Does that make sense? Let me know otherwise!

column8:
I have done many other Cousera courses and found the quality of the captions to be variable, particularly if they were non-American accents. Some courses have helpful students who post updated versions of the captions but obviously that takes some effort and is subject to a delay. It is unfortunate for those who are not native English speakers (or are hearing impaired) and rely on the captions but manually transcribing all the lectures is an intensive task and for a free course it would be a significant overhead. As it is, the lecturers, their students and administrators, and the forum TAs all give their time with no financial reward. These MOOCs have tens of thousands of enrollees  and tailoring the course for the benefit of every individual is not feasible, so it is inevitable that some will feel dissatisfied with the product or be unable to keep up with the schedule.
I have enrolled in over a dozen courses but have not been able to keep up with all of them owing to real-world obligations. So I persist with some to get the personal satisfaction of the certificate but with others I download all the course materials to enjoy in my own time and for my own self-education. Coursera is an amazing free resource and I am grateful for whatever I can get out of it.

column2: Lectures / Week 3 / Functions, Variables and the Call Stack
column8: If you step through the visualiser you can see that the definitions of the functions is part of the main procedure. However, when those functions are called they open up a new frame in the stack with their own records which are then erased when the function is closed. If a function calls another function then multiple frames are opened. These are what need to be counted for the quiz.

column8: Once you understand what a 'frame' is - and many people have been confused, judging by some other threads - then if you step through the visualiser the answer is easy. When you run through the debugger you execute one step of the program at a time. By doing this you can see how the loop executes. If it stops at the first return statement it means that there is a flaw in your logic. The debugger can't tell you what that is but it should cause you to examine how you expect the program to operate.

If I wanted a qualification then I would need to enrol in a course with a much more rigorous examination process. column8: One way of making the random function less predictable is to use the current time - seconds, or microseconds if available - as a seed.

What is required is that you enter 2 DNA strings and an insertion point. The first string is arbitrarily split somewhere so you just need to slice from the beginning up to the insertion point, add the second string and then add the remainder of the first string - which is basically another slice from the same point to the end. The code is effectively just two slices and then concatenating three strings.

        can bring up different questions and you need to check your answers each time you make a new submission -ï_ which can be a bit of a pain if you only got one wrong and wanted to improve your score.

There is nothing to stop you doing the Learn to Program: Crafting Quality Code module now. The only thing is that there is no peer feedback and you won't get a certificate, but if you want to learn you can still sign up and have access to the course materials. I downloaded it all this morning.

column8: Read the assignment again. One of the arguments to the function is the position at which the second string is inserted in the first string. It can be the beginning, the end or any point in between the two. What you need to do is write the code for two slices. One from the beginning of the string to the insertion point, and another from the insertion point to the end. You can use defaults for the beginning and end (don't bother with determining the string length).

Igor, there are many thousands of people doing these courses, extensions are simply not possible unless there has been a major problem on the Coursera side. column13: How old is too old to start a career in coding?

column8: I'm sorry to say that once the bus has left then you've missed it. Everyone has the same information about deadlines and with thousands of people doing the course, the 'dog ate my homework' line doesn't carry much weight. If this is just a  single occasion then you should be able to attain the certificate by completing all the other exercises/assignments and doing well enough in the final exam. Good luck!

This is my tenth (or so) Coursera course and I see that this is a perennial problem for people who do not have the same reliability of internet and electricity that we take for granted in much of the west. I'm afraid that I can't offer much hope for you as the whole Coursera model is based on having an Internet connection. If you want get a certificate then you need to ensure that you complete all the exercises and assignments in good time. It is actually feasible to get the certificate of completion even if you don't do the final exam, providing that your other course work is of a high enough standard.
If you really want/need to complete the final exam then you should take whatever steps possible to ensure that you have the most reliable connection possible or have a backup strategy. So I would suggest that you only attempt the exam at a time of day when you can be relatively confident of a continuous connection, perhaps at night when others are asleep or when there is less demand on the local infrastructure. Make sure that you download and save as much as possible of the exam before attempting the questions so that you can work offline if necessary and upload when you regain a connection.  Also don't leave it until the last minute, try and plan your time well in advance. I appreciate your concerns but these courses have so many students that making exceptions for a small minority is not fair for the majority. It sounds heartless, I know, but these courses are free and tailoring them to a minority of students in special circumstances is not a practical proposition.  So I wish you good luck and hope that you manage to complete the course without any problems.

column2: Lectures / Week 6 / for loop over indices
column8: Basically whatever is on the left of the "=" (assignment operator) gets the value of what is on the right. So to shift everything left you need to save the value of the lowest index and then let it equal whatever is contained in the next index higher. By doing this for every index, everything is shifted one position to the left except for the highest index which is then assigned what was in the lowest index.

column8:
IntroNext to
this course I_‹_m trying to learn programming with Python by writing own programs
based upon what we learn from this course and other sources. In the best case
these would be programs which could really help me out with certain activities
and everyday live. So I tried to think of a subject I could experiment with and
which could eventually provide me with a very handy program. 

This brought me to the issue of having too many passwords to be able to
remember them all, while not wanting to write them down because somebody might
find it and while not wanting to reuse the same passwords for different
applications because that would increase the risks. 
The program
The last few courses brought me to an idea. I could write a program which would
first of all try to recognize me by asking something only I could know. It
could be a password or something else. By giving that it would grant me access.
After having access I would have to call a function, different ones for
different passwords and applications. After calling the function Python will
then give me the correct password. And here comes the tricky part, I would not
want the function to just return a password as a string because that would be
very weak. I would like it to form the password by getting every letter one by one
as a substring from a large index/list of letters. The list would contain the alphabet
several times but then not in the logical order we are used to but in a random
order. The function would have to return the different letters by searching for
their index number within the list and then concatenate them with each other
and print them as a string which would be the password. 
Reasons why?
- With this code I would not have to write my passwords on a sheet of paper or
a document on my computer so nobody can find it. 
- I would have to write it in the python.py document but that would not matter
because I assume the average person from where I live does not know how to
program with python and without that knowledge they could open and read but not
understand the code. 
- Even if they would have some knowledge working with the large list would make
it very time consuming and difficult to find the letters, because it would be a
maze of many letters in a random order. 
- It would also not matter if somebody would run the program because they would
need to answer the first question.
- If there would be somebody knowledgeable enough to hack the program then it
would not matter because with or without the program he would have known enough
to hack it anyways ï_:P. 
- I could also give the program and document a misleading name and not
something like password.py.

To sum it up it would be an easy program to write, using the methods we learned
in week 1 to 4. It would make it possible for me to find password I forget and
save them in a safe way. 
Where you can help meI would like to know what you guys think about this. Critique about the method
is more than welcome. 
- Could you name certain weaknesses? 
- Could you think of a better method which would still be possible to write
with the knowledge only attained from the first 4 weeks? 

PS: I assume programs for this already exist. I know they are much better and
safer. But as I said it is not only useful but it is also a way of learning for
me and it gives a feeling of comfort to work with programs you have made
yourself.

Hi folks. Here's my (non recursive) attempt.  
def Fib_list(n):	L = list()	L.append(0)	if n > 1:		L.append(1)		a = 0		b = 1		c = 3		while c <= n:			a += b			L.append(a)			xor = a ^ b #			a ^= xor    # poor man's SWAP			b ^= xor    #			c += 1	print('Finished calculations')	print(L)

HelloThanks for this exercise.Here's my suggestion :def Roots(number,root): return number ** (1 / root)def Power(number, exponent): return number ** exponentI had to "cheat" for the root part, i.e. finding the equivalent between x Root(number) and number Exp(1/x)
Ah, thanks! Convenient, and definitely more elegant. Perlish.

Hello! Here's my suggestion:

def Alpha_shift(sentence, shift):	'''(string,int) -> string	return a string where letters have been shifted <shift> rows to the left of to the right. A positive <shift> value will shift letters to the right ; negative to the left.	Example :	Alpha_shift('this is a test', 2)			vjku ku c vguv'''	# initialise result string	shifted_sentence = ''		# ensure <shift> stays within a range of [0..25]	shift %= 26	# variable <character> will iterate through each character in <sentence>	for character in sentence:				# if character is alphabetic		if character.isalpha():			# if lower case letter			if character.islower(): shifted_sentence += chr(97 + (ord(character) - 71 + shift) % 26)			# if upper case letter			else: shifted_sentence += chr(65 + (ord(character) - 39 + shift) % 26)				# otherwise, append non-alphabetic characters without any processing		else: shifted_sentence += character		return shifted_sentence    # UPDATED TO INCLUDE isalpha() AND islower()To
cipher a string, use :
Alpha_shift(string, numeric_shift)
And to decipher :
Alpha_shift(string, - numeric_shift)
Thanks for posting programming challenges!

Hello!Here's my suggestion :def Combinations(nbr_letters):	combinations = []	# list of combinations (type string)	codes = []		# list of letter ASCII codes for current combination		# initialise combination	for i in range(0, nbr_letters): codes.append(65)		last = nbr_letters - 1	# index of last letter in combination		while True:				# convert numeric combination to string representation		combination = ''		for i in codes: combination += chr(i)				# store string representation of current combination		combinations.append(combination)				# if last letter is 'Z' (ASCII 90)		if codes[last] == 90:						# set to 'A'			codes[last] = 65						# initialise index of previous letter			i = last - 1						# while index of previous letter is valid			while i >= 0:								# if previous letter is 'Z'				if codes[i] == 90:										# set to 'A'					codes[i] = 65										# move one letter backward (and re-enter loop)					i -= 1				else:										# increment letter					codes[i] += 1										# exit from loop					break						# this part is executed when the while condition evaluates to false (*not* through a "break" statement). Practically, it means that the following code will be executed when all letters are 'Z'			else:				# exit from main loop (refers to "while True")				break				# if last letter isn't 'Z'		else:			# increment letter			codes[last] += 1		print('(All combinations found)')	for combination in combinations: print(combination)Sorry if it's neither elegant nor simple.And thanks for posting a challenge!

column8: Hello DianeThank you for your comment.Concerning the character-set, the function was intentionally coded to shift only alphabetic characters regardless of case, preserving capitalisation, punctuation and all non-alphabetic content.As to the "greater than" sign, where in the code do you think it would be needed?

Of course, there's more than one way to approach a problem, and nobody's claiming to hold the ultimate solution. Besides, being a total beginner in Python, I think code optimisation concerns should come at a later time, when we're better acquainted with Python's idioms. But it's only my approach.

Hello LakkaMay I contribute?Your code first converts the sentence to lower case, but, later on, tests whether letters are lower case or not. Perhaps you could change "for letter in sentence.lower()" to "for letter in sentence", and rely on the "if letter.islower()" conditional statement.By the way, it's "islower()" (without parentheses, it seemingly evaluates to method address).It's very convenient that Python has built-in string methods such as isalpha and islower!

Hello DianeA few remarks on your code.Your code refers to shift as a global variable in function find_let, but you commented out its declaration, which results in a compile (or whatever the name of that stage) error. Besides, If you want shift to be a global variable, you needn't pass it as an argument to translate().Another issue is that when shift is assigned user input in caesar(), it really is a local variable (no global declaration there), and (global) variable shift in function find_let() doesn't refer to the same variable. Addingdef caesar():ï_ï_ï_ global shiftwill fix this.Global variable caes is initialised to a list containing an empty string as its first element. The following would do just fine :caes = []With caes being defined as global, it means that function translate() appends characters to global variable caes, then returns it, which is in turn assigned to local variable caes in function caesar().alph is used in your code to test if a character is lower case alphabetic, to return its numeric index, or to return the letter corresponding to a numeric index. Now that you're more familiar with ASCII codes, you could use the ord() function to get letter codes, chr() to get letter from code, and Python's built-in string method isalpha() (as illustrated by Lakka's post below) to test if characters belong to the alphabet.Furthermore, you define variables c and d as global, and initialise them to an empty string. C is used in translate() and d in find_let() but nowhere in those functions are they declared as global, so it means that global variables c and d are practically never used.Finally, concerning your find_let() function, if you wish to make your code shorter, you can notice that you d = alph[t] assignment occurs in both parts of your conditional test. You can safely move this assignment outside of it, like this :def find_let(b):    global shift, t, ceas    if b + shift >= 26:        t = int((b + shift) % 26)    else:        t = int(b + shift)    d = alph[t]    return dHere's an update suggestion for your code (tested in IDLE).

Hello! Here is my attempt :def trip_time():    # initialise <place> and <total_time>    place = 'place1'    total_time = time_to_go(place)    # add time for next places to go    while place != 'place4':        place = next_place(place)        total_time += time_to_go(place)    return total_time    def round_trip():    total_time = trip_time()    return '{:02d}:{:02d}:{:02d}'.format(int(total_time // 60), int(total_time % 60), int((total_time * 60) % 60))Thanks for the exercise!

welcome :-)
Looks definitely Pythonic (Pythonish?) ... and somewhat mysterious too. Good going!

Like this?def XOR_sentence(sentence, encoding):        '''(str, str) -> str        Perform a binary XOR on all characters of <sentence>        with those of <encoding> string. If <encoding> string is shorter than        <sentence>, its characters are cyclically repeated        to match <sentence> length.        The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog!   <<< source string        a cipher testa cipher testa cipher testa cip   <<< encoding string        Example :        XOR_sentence('The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog','a cipher test')        >>> '5Hx06Ix01x1dx0cx11KTx07x01x1bx16NCx0fx1fx10Ex18Ux19x15x00Tx0eVx06x1bPx1crx17x00x18x04trADx0cx0e'        XOR_sentence('5Hx06Ix01x1dx0cx11KTx07x01x1bx16NCx0fx1fx10Ex18Ux19x15x00Tx0eVx06x1bPx1crx17x00x18x04trADx0cx0e','a cipher test')        >>> 'The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog'        '''        return ''.join([chr(c) for c in [ord(sentence[i]) ^ ord(encoding[i % len(encoding)]) for i in range(len(sentence))]])
It was poor wording on my part, sorry. I just meant that the "zip()" seemed exotic to the beginner that I am. Taking a closer look at it now, it looks like a multiple list iteration tool.

column8: @ EtienneAgreed! Here's a another variation:def sym_string(sentence, key):        '''(str, str) -> str        Return a string consisting of each character of <sentence>        mirrored against the corresponding character of <key>.        Mirroring is defined as taking the symmetrical opposite of a character        within a character set.        a b c d e f g h i j k l m n o p q r s t u v w x y z   <<< char-set                      |       |       |          mirrored ----       |       --- input character          character           |                               ---- key = axis        Formula : mirrored = (len(charset) + key + (key - input)) % len(charset)        Note : the character-set can also be randomly shuffled. The sequence of random values that are generated is dependant on <key>        Example :        sym_string('The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy coder','This is a test')        >>> 'Thd H]R&l S"l(! ~w$ 9|c3k 9,Mv ZN_ ua~- &}DV"'                The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy coder   <<< each character of this, is mirrored        This is a testThis is a testThis is a testThi   <<< against each character of this                '''        import string        import random                # build a list of printable characters, except whitespace        charset = [i for i in iter(string.ascii_letters + string.digits + string.punctuation)]        length_charset = len(charset)        # strip <key> of those characters not found in char-set        key = ''.join([key[i] if key[i] in charset else '' for i in range(len(key))])        # randomise charset        random.seed(key)        for i in range(length_charset):                j = int(random.random() * length_charset)                charset[i], charset[j] = charset[j], charset[i]        return ''.join( [                        charset[                               (length_charset + 2 * charset.index(key[i % len(key)]) - charset.index(sentence[i])) % length_charset                               ]                               if sentence[i] in charset else sentence[i]                        for i in range(len(sentence))                        ]                      )

Hi folks!Here's my attempt :def Collatz_sequence(n):        '''(int) -> sequence of integer        Given number <n>, return the sequence of integers generated        by applying the Collatz formula.        Precondition : n is a positive integer        Example :        >>> Collatz_sequence(10)        [10, 5, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1]        '''        sequence = [n]        while n != 1:                                n = n // 2 if n % 2 == 0 else 3 * n + 1                sequence.append(n)        return sequencedef Collatz_seq_length(n):        '''(int) -> int        Return the length of a Collatz sequence for a given number <n>        (without actually determining the sequence contents).        Example :        >>> Collatz_sequence(10)        7                '''        length = 1        while n != 1:                n = n // 2 if n % 2 == 0 else 3 * n + 1                length += 1        return lengthdef Collatz_biggest_sequence(n):        # brute force approach        '''(int) -> int        return the integer from range [2 .. <n>], which produces        the longest Collatz sequence. The "brute-force" approach consists        in calculating sequence length for every number of the input range.        Example :        >>> Collatz_biggest_sequence(1000)        871        '''        winning_number = 2        max_length = 2                for i in range(2, n + 1):                length = Collatz_seq_length(i)                if length > max_length:                        max_length = length                        winning_number = i        return winning_numberdef Collatz_biggest_sequence2(n):        # "I've already done that" approach        '''(int) -> int        return the integer from range [2 .. <n>], which produces        the longest Collatz sequence. This function keeps track of already        calculated sequence lengths. For instance, if we already know that        number 3 produces an 8 member sequence, to determine the length for        number 12 we only need apply the Collatz formula twice :        12 => 6        6 => 3        and add 2 to the already known sequence length for number 3.        Example :        >>> Collatz_biggest_sequence(1000)        871                '''        known = {1: 1}        max_length = 1        winning_number = 1        for i in range(2, n + 1):                n = i                length = 0                while not n in known:                        length += 1                        n = n // 2 if n % 2 == 0 else 3 * n + 1                known[i] = known[n] + length                        for i in known.keys():                if known[i] > max_length:                        max_length = known[i]                        winning_number = i        return winning_number# --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- ---def Print_sequence(n):        # for task 1        seq = Collatz_sequence(n)        print('Collatz sequence for', n, 'is :n')        print(', '.join([str(i) for i in seq]))        print('n(',len(seq),' elements)', sep='')        def Print_longest_sequence(n):        # for task 2        i = Collatz_biggest_sequence2(n)        print('Of all numbers up to', n,', number', i, 'produces the longest sequence.')        Print_sequence(i)                          Tasks #1 and #2 are handled by the last two routines.

column8: Citing the IDLE help() function about and :The expression x and y first evaluates x; if x is false, itsvalue is returned; otherwise, y is evaluated and the resulting valueis returned.Note that neither and nor or restrict the value and type theyreturn to False and True, but rather return the last evaluatedargument.cents is evaluated to True (non-zero), so it evaluates dollars and returns its value.But if you had written :cents = 0dollars = 53the expression cents and dollars would evaluate to 0 (as the first value equates to False)Hope that helps!

Thanks for your comment, Michael, and I'm glad if you found this code useful to get started on the second part. I am not very comfortable with recursion, but yes, you can calculate the length using recursion, just like the code you've posted below, it's very good.Also, don't let my lengthy code postings give you false impressions, I'm a beginner just like you, only with some Perl background :-)I hope to see your solution to part #2 (even if you feel like copying someone else in the beginning, you'll take ownership of the code in the process of writing and you will perhaps find new ways --- try it!).
Shouldn't a variable that represents whether a non-nucleotide was found be initialised to False, and set to True if a non-nucleotide character is found, or am I just tired?

Sorry, I was focusing on the wording, here.A Boolean variable that represents whether you have found a non-nucleotide characterHow would you interpret such a variable holding the True value?Since it represents whether a non-nucleotide character has been found, if it's True, then it means the sequence is unvalid. Then according to the description :the variable is initialised to True (a non-nucleotide has been found, and the sequence is invalid)the variable is set to False (no invalid character found) if you find something that isn't a nucleotideIt simply doesn't make sense.Either that Boolean variable represents whether all the characters are valid :all_valid is initialised to Trueall_valid is set to False if you find something that isn't an 'A', 'T', 'C' or 'G'or the variable really indicates if a non-nucleotide was found and non_nucleotide_found is initialised to Falsenon_nucleotide_found is set to True if you find something that isn't an 'A', 'T', 'C' or 'G'

No I'm not "overthinking", I'm reporting what I believe to be an illogical phrasing.My post isn't concerned with the purpose of the function "is_valid_sequence". It is fairly obvious that its return value should reflect whether an invalid character was found or not.My point is that a Boolean variable that is said "to represent whether a non-nucleotide was found", shouldn't be initialised to True and set to False upon encountering a non-nucleotide character.That wording is illogical.

>> the boolean does not hold the value of whether a non-nucleotide sequence was foundNo kidding?So, when you read this sentence:use a Boolean variable that represents whether you have found a non-nucleotide characteryou understand that "the boolean does not hold the value of whether a non-nucleotide sequence was found"?

What I mean is, the phrasing would make more sense (to me) if the original text:Another way is to use a Boolean variable that represents whether you have found a non-nucleotide character; it would start off as True and would be set to False if you found something that wasn't an 'A', 'T', 'C' or 'G'.was changed into :Another way is to use a Boolean variable that represents whether you have found a non-nucleotide character; it would start off as False and would be set to True if you found something that wasn't an 'A', 'T', 'C' or 'G'.

>> It never says to set it to True if you find one, in fact it says just the oppositeOn this we agree. It says to set it to False if you find one. And that's the problem.Yes, there is a whole sentence there, and that whole sentence suggests using a variable that represents whether a non-nucleotide was found, initialise it to True and set it to false if you find incorrect characters. A more logical approach (and wording), in my opinion, would recommend setting the opposite values.

Made the same mistake :-)They seem to consider that a zero length sequence is valid.You should have something likestudent: test_a2.TestIsValidSequence.test_is_valid_sequence_zero_lengthin your assignment report, but are there other problems reported?
Yes, zero-length is valid.
Thank you Kevin, and I apologize for prompting such a lengthy thread over a language detail.

Was not much inspired by prime numbers.Here is to test primality:def is_prime(number):    for n in range(2, int(number ** 0.5) + 1):        if number % n == 0:            print("found divisor", n)            return False    else: return TrueAnd this, to find a list of prime numbers:def prime_list(number):    primes = []    limit = None    for n in range(2, number + 1):        limit = int(n ** 0.5)        for divisor in primes:            if n % divisor == 0: break            elif divisor > limit:                primes.append(n)                break        else: primes.append(n)    return primes

column8: You actually don't need to know too much to do such a thing. First downloadï_http://www.autohotkey.com/It's open source and free, code is even more basic than in Python (though java and strings can be used but I don't)Code is something like: {CTRLDOWN}{UP}{CTRLUP}.This is the other thing you need:http://www.free-ocr.com/Why do you need OCR Image to text recognition?ï_For two reasons: Firstly the error message might not be a text you can just select in blue. Secondly because sometimes windows move and Autohotkey does not automatically recognize that, so even if you would be able to select text if the error message doesn't pop-up as usual in the center part of the screen the code wouldn't work.So here's how to do it:- Build an .AHK script that shoots screenshots of the PC you want to monitor (you'll probably need to learn somethings like this symbol: '!' actually means ALT in Autohotkey. Ok, so then transform those screenshots into OCR by copy pasting the screenshot in the website (that must be done by the same script that took the screenshot and you'll probably need to run some tests for the "Sleep, 5000" code that will wait for the website to load).The final part I don't know it, it's entirely up to you. I'm pretty sure you'll need a string or if statements, that recognize if there's an error message. Maybe the easiest way to do it is to hide the Icons so that the screenshot will not see any words unless an error message pops-up.I'm not an expert programmer but I hope this workaround suits for you.

column8: # ï_ ï_ 1. The expressions that make up the actual parameters are evaluated,# ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_and the formal parameters of the function are bound to the resulting values.# ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_for example, the invocation sqrt(16) will bind the formal parameter x to 16.## ï_ ï_ ï_2. The point of execution (the next instruction to be executed) moves from the# ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_the point of invocation to the first statement in the body of the function.## ï_ ï_ ï_3. The code in the body of the function is executed until either a return statement# ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_is encountered, in which case the value of the expression following the return# ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_becomes the value of the function invocation. If no expression follows the return,# ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_then the value of invocation is None.## ï_ ï_ ï_4. The value of the invocation is the returned value.## ï_ ï_ ï_5. The point of execution is transferred back to the code immedietly following the invocation.#"From the book introduction computation and programming using python" by professor John Guttag from MIT.

column8: you are defining functions in the shell. this is possible, but it is much easier to separate the function definitions from the function calls. define functions in the editor and call the functions in the shell.howto1. open editor: file - new window2. define one or more functions in the editor: def square_print(num): etc...3. save your function(s) in a file: file - save as - any_name.py4. run the module (file) in the shell: run module5. call the function in the shell: square_print(4)this procedure is shown in the video 'defining functions' around 4:48.ï_

column8: objects are a special datatype which contain attributes and methods:1. object.attribute- retrieve attribute of object- i think the course did not cover the topic of attributes yet, so i won't either.- object.method without the brackets does not exist2. object.method()- dot notation- call method on object- e.g. 'abc'.find('a') returns 0 (because first occurence of 'a' is at index 0)3. method(object)- some common methods have a different/shorter syntaxï_- e.g. len('abc') returns 3- you maybe would expect 'abc'.len(). this is wrong. - 'abc'.__len__() does exist and also returns 3reference: type help(str) in IDLEï_

column8: i am a beginner and no authority on this matter, but this is how i see it:theoryfunctional programming and object-oriented programming are two different perspectives to solve problems using code. The world of functional programming uses functions to construct programs and does not use classes, objects or methods. The world of object-oriented programming uses classes, objects and methods to construct programs and does not use functions.ï_practiceIn Python we can use both perspectives and mix them up. method(object) is syntax from the object-oriented world, which produces the same outcome asï_function(x) from the functional programming world.ï_

I'm here because I think it's really important to become tech literate in this current age which to me means understanding how certain machines and programmes are built and then being able to build them yourself.I'm planning on using this course to discover the basics of programming so that I can start creating apps (using java/android) and other hardware setups (e.g. with the raspberry pi) which are tailored towards my life. It will also help me in my current job as a scientist. And if I'm lucky I might even make a career out of it!

Gerry, I was thinking about taking that course after I finish this one.It looks like a really good way to consolidate whatever I learn here.

Although I'm not a staff member I think it should be OK.The honour code seems to be more of a 'give your word' type of thing as opposed to a sealed digital contract which tracks what you are doing. For example it would be pretty easy for you to take the homework and then just Google the questions if you wanted. It goes against the spirit of the course in that you won't necessarily be learning anything, but it would be more or less impossible to track (without illegal breaches of your privacy).I'm pretty sure you can use the same computer. The point is to really just not look at each others work and try to complete assignments yourself. Aside from that it's probably advisable to study with each other and discuss mistakes you make, it would make a better learning experience for you both if you encouraged and supported each other. Just don't cheat.

column2: Exercises and Assignments / Exercise 2 / Question 14 discussion
column8: The trick, which I'm not sure was put across very clearly in the videos, is that you can call a function inside the parameters of another function. Essentially making the argument for one function from the product of another function.I don't think I could say anymore without seriously giving the answer away.Edit: I'm a fool, I'm talking about question 15.14 is really simple if you think about it. You don't need to come up with any new functions or find an already existent function from Pythons database. Just think about the mathematics of a vowels and consonants to words.

column2: Exercises and Assignments / Exercise 2 / Question 14 discussion
column8: Anon is right, one of your attempts is correct aside from your parameters.Remember you are writing out the body of a function so there are a couple things you can't do. One is to enter an argument. You do that when you call the function. Instead when defining a function you replace an argument with an arbitrary value (such as word - notice the lack of quotation marks) to represent its parameters.Secondly you can't name the function in it's own body unless as a comment.if we are defining the function num_mountains, then our body cant be:ï_ ï_ return num_mountains(mountains1(num) + mountains2(num))This is because 'num_mountains' isn't yet defined (because we are currently defining it) so will create an error. mountains1(num) and mountains2(num) we assume were created previously before we defined this function.This particular exercise is nothing to do with defining the number of letters in 'hello' it's about defining a function that could tell you the number of letters in any word ('hello' included)From experience I also have to tell you that one of the most frustrating problems in getting your code wrongs can be small spelling mistakes or switched words. They are simple issues which by and large don't mean you misunderstood, just that you made a small mistake.

There are a lot of languages out there and no direct progression from one to another so it's really up to you.In terms of apps ios and android have their own languages so it would be worth learning one of those if you want to learn to make apps. Android is heavily based on Java so that's a good start, both java and android have lots of free online and interactive courses, give it a google. Ios I'm less sure of but apple tends to use objective-c, it might be worth looking around for more info.

So I submitted and got fails on the last two functions for reasons I very much understand and have now fixed.My problem is that the functions are supposed to output a float, whereas I'm using a modulo to generate an accurate answer (which matches all of the examples given) but outputs as an int.My question is whether I can make the modulo output a float? or do I have to find another way around the problem?

Might be a problem with your browser/computer.Try Chrome or Firefox or an alternative browser to what you are using now. It matters in a sense because of how computer memory works and the order in which it executes commands.You are right in thinking that the computer could attempt to change x=1 (where 1 is stored at id1) to x=2 (where 2 is stored at id2) whilst keeping the same memory address and just overwriting the data. However this creates a couple problems. Namely, the computer doesn't know how big a piece of data it is going to store, and this may not match up to the size of the previous data in some way.As a result Python keeps things running safely by always assigning a new memory address to all pieces of data so as to stop any errors occuring in it's own memory.By doing this id1 does become defunct for a fraction of a second. However the garbage collector regularly sweeps through the memory addresses and gets rid of any useless data which isn't attached to any variables/sections of code. So even though id1 is made momentarily useless, it will be available again as soon as the next command is executed.Realistically if you kept changing x from 1 to 2 to 3 etc. you wouldn't go from id1 to id2 to id 3 etc. you would just cycle back and forth between id1 and id2 as each is cleared after they become useless.This is based off of my rudimentary knowledge so anyone is welcome to come and correct me if I got something wrong!

I haven't put in any floats as a calculation (I'm only using the examples) but as long as there's no decimal, then it returns as an int and not a float (e.g. 5, as opposed to 5.0).I submitted my code again and it passed 41/41 but it still bugs me a bit...

column8: Because it is not an inbuilt function. It's a made up function for the purposes of this exercise. To run it in IDLE you would have to first create the function.

To simplify the above.Memory addresses are only limited by the amount of memory your computer has. (I'm not very knowledgeable about hardware but I assume we're talking RAM memory and not hard drive memory.). However the amount of memory addresses your computer can hold is probably far more than you'll ever need.That said memory addresses can be reused assuming that they have no function. For example let's assume you've assigned a value of 12 to variable number (number = 12). This means that number is now connected to memory address x1 which holds the value 12. Now let's change the value of number to 30 (number = 30). Now number is connected to the memory address x2 which holds the value 30.By doing this x1 has become useless as it isn't connected to any variable. The garbage collector (a specialist part of Python) regularly scans through the memory addresses looking for ones which have become useless, like x1, and clears them. So almost immediately after the value of number is changed, x1 becomes useless and is cleared by the garbage collector. As a result of x1 being cleared it becomes available for use again and you can assign it a new value.This is just a nifty way for Python to decrease errors in memory storage when you may have overlapping memory addresses which are to big or small for their relative stacks of data.
As far as I understand y wouldn't refer to the phrase x+2, it just refers to the product of the sum. I'm not sure about this though.

My knowledge is only limited when it comes to memory addresses. But in that example there are two possibilities, I'm not sure which is correct.In one possibility x = 1 assumes id1, not because 1 was in id1 before, but because when you changed x to 7 id1 was cleared and made available again.In te other possibility x will relate to id4. This is because although you have changed x, y still relates to the original value and therefore the original memory address, so id1 is still being used.In my opinion the first option is more likely. I think, but I'm not sure, that y wouldn't relate to the original x + 2, but instead will just relate to the product of the calculation (3). So id2 will = 3, not x+2. If this is the case then changing x will certainly make id1 redundant.It's probably better if someone more knowledgeable confirmed though before you trust me!

Yes, Maybe, No?Lots of questions and the answer is often the same: it really depends on what you want to do. Which you've eluded to.For me I work in a science lab and MatLab is used everyday which requires it's own coding language. I haven't used it myself yet and everyone I've talked to praise it as a magical power. What I've found is that in around 200 people, one person can code it effectively. So I thought I'd learn how coding works.I started with the codecademy tracks (HTML, CSS, JavaScript) having absolutely no idea what I was doing. It was fun and I learnt a lot, especially with JavaScript, but I realised I don't really want to do much WebDev. So I've settled for trying to do things which are functional (make personalised apps, create hardware designed for my life with Raspberry Pi). Looking around at what I need for these aims I've found Java and Python. Python is the primary language used for Raspberry Pi and is a recommended beginner language as it is simple and easy to learn. It's also supposed to be similar to Java and C so should be a good starting point to learn other more advanced languages.Java is next because it is the primary basis for making Android apps.Essentially my scaffold is/was: Start learning so I can get a grasp of what the hell I'm getting myself into.Figure out what the hell I want to do.Research to find out what's needed/fits my wants.Start with the easiest language and do a few courses.Practice with first language, build a few things if possible (I'm already planning a game).Start more advanced language.Build with advanced language.???Profit.For specific constellations of programming languages? I'm not entirely sure of all of them but I have a hazy idea of a few.Web Dev: HTML and CSS are essential. Then JavaScript and PHP.Gaming production: Varies for what you're designing it for. Web games: JavaScript will do.Computer games/Video games: Really varies, but Java and C++ are probably a good start, maybe C.Computer software/programmes: For Microsoft use C#, Apple uses objective-C. Not sure about Linux.Apps: Andoird uses Java. ios uses objective-cAnalysis(Financial, Science, Marketing etc.): This gets really complicated. MatLab is the general language used for Scientific research that I know of. Although I know a few computer science labs use R to design analytical software. For finance and marketing, which requires analysis of large databases, a lot of people tend to use SQL (or MySQL - Oracles version of SQL). Realistically MatLab could probably do a lot of this stuff but it is used on expensive and specialist software, MySQL is fairly accessible and there are open-source versions of it.Another language worth a shout is Scratch. It's a new language designed in MIT for educational purposes. It's extremely basic and very visual, which makes it ideal for teaching kids how to programme. But although it looks much more basic then anything we learn here, it is still capable of designing things like games and so on.I have no idea what is best for code-breaking. But as cryptography is heavily based on mathematics and algorithms, I reckon it will be more about how good your maths is, as opposed to which languages you know.Nevertheless, do some research yourself, and when it comes to solving a problem and which specific language to use, you'll probably know once you've learnt a couple!

column8: So I'm questioning the ability to hide the passwords.You want to hide them in a random string of letters? Ok. So how is that going to work?Are you asking it to pull out specific letters from specific strings to form your password? Or is there a specific string within a string which is your password or answer?You will in the end have to create if statements which define what the answers are (if "xxxx" then give password etc.). and more to the point the code will have to have a way of producing the actual password (password = x from sting 1 + y from string b etc.)Maybe I'm missing the point here but will it work?Alternatives I can think is giving the file a random name which you remember (flrblwswartz or something) and encrypting the folder which it is in. Then instead of opening the file directly you could run it as a module in Python. As you know the name you can always get access. Then you continue with your other levels of security.A good encryption will be impossible to break and will stop anyone from seeing your code. From then on the only way someone can use your code is if they a: know the name of the module, b: understand how the functions work. and c: know the answers to your questions.The only other possibility is to use a bit of cryptography and instead of producing your password produce a formulaic product of your password (a simple version would be to produce every letter +2 of it's value, e.g. instead of a produce c, or instead of f produce h. You can make it far more complicated though.).Nevertheless good luck!

            data = data+i
            #append piece of data to inner list
            dox.append(data)

column8: It's possible!Although the guys over at stackoverflow told me I was screwing around too much by making my own parsing code (the one above) which would run through a CSV file and create a python list. Instead I should use the much more efficient and specially designed csv.reader() function, which I am now doing.I've come on a bit since this problem, although I'm taking a break at the moment. My code is complete in theory, but doesn't work because the amount of data I want to process is simply too much for a list (my code has to do over a trillion calculations which crashes IDLE). So I'm going to try rewrite the code to read and write each individual line to a file simultaneously, so python never has to keep too much data open, and to change everything into dictionary format so I don't have to iterate over every single inner list when running my conversion programme.

I've had so much trouble opening files for reading and using them. For the last few days I've been playing with.txt and .csv files for a future project and I eventually got it working.Here is my code with comments:from tkinter.filedialog import askopenfile

# Create a variable for the file

file = askopenfile()

#create some empty variables

doc = []

dox = []

data = ''

#turn the lines into a list
lines = file.readlines()

#read through the list item by item to create inner lists

for line in lines:
    # clean any required variables for each loop
    data = ''
    dox = []
    for i in line:
        #grab individual characters and combine/separate into actual data
        #according to the separator: in a .csv file this would be the comma.
        if i != ',':
            data = data+i
        else:
            #append comma for completeness
            data = data+i
            #append piece of data to inner list
            dox.append(data)
            #clean required variable
            data = ''
    #append inner list to outer list
    doc.append(dox)What this is essentially doing is opening a file using tkinter and assigning it to a variable. Then I read the file and assign the read file into a variable (past this point if I read the file any further I will just get '', so it would be worth using file.close() to close the file to be reopened later.The rest of the code runs through the newest variable line by line, transferring each line into a list, which is then appended to another list. So in the end I have an overall list which contains inner lists, each one containing its own line.

I should add that it's not recommended to create a parsing code (like the one above) for .csv files as they have a builtin module already. I have since rewritten most of my code for .csv files but this should work for anything that's .txt.

You don't need to open anything in your code. That is done for you in the driver file, which is supplementary to what the a3.py file.What you essentially need to do is create a programme which reads (iterates, loops, however you want to 'read' a file in python) ï_and creates a new list which contains either the board or the words.Check out the docstring which tells you what is going in and coming out. Note how both state (file open for reading) -> List of xxxxxx.That is because the file is already open for reading. You just need to convert the open file into the given format.

I'm not too sure what you're asking, but if you're asking whether when you open the programme that every possible variable is assigned to 0, then I believe that is not true.Instead there simply are no variables. you have to create one before it is assigned anything, otherwise you would have an infinite list of variables relating to 0, which your computer, or any computer for that matter wouldn't be able to deal with.

column8: The following excerpt is taken fromï_http://www.tutorialspoint.com/python/python_basic_syntax.htmPython Identifiers:A Python identifier is a name used to identify a variable, function, class, module or other object. An identifier starts with a letter A to Z or a to z or an underscore (_) followed by zero or more letters, underscores and digits (0 to 9).Python does not allow punctuation characters such as @, $ and % within identifiers. Python is a case sensitive programming language. Thus,ï_Manpowerï_andï_manpowerï_are two different identifiers in Python.

Clarifying the scope of list used in the example. ï_When the list is passed to the function what is being passed is the memory address of the list. ï_That makes the changesï_permanent, the same outside of the function.Similar to using pointers in C. ï_The data at the memory address was changed so the function doesn't have to return the new value to keep the changes from disappearing with the function end.

First of all, % is not technically the remainder, it's called the Modulo function.Since there are different ways of thinking of remainders when working with negative numbers, I'll explain how to think about Python, Modulo, and remainders.For A % BFirst Python finds the largest integer multiple of B which is not larger than A, in your example this is -24Then Python calculates how much larger A is compared to that number, the difference between the two numbers. So how much larger than -24 is -1? You do this by subtraction: -1 - (-24) = 23. This can be confusing, because you're not using the absolute value of the numbers. It can help to visualize it on a number line:<-------(-24)----------------------(-1)--0----------------->-1 is 23 spaces to the right of -24, which is the answer that Python gives us.Let's try another example, with negative numbers:-30%24the largest multiple of 24 that isn't higher than -30 is -48, so we can subtract -48 from -30 and that gives us 18to look on a number line, -30 is 18 spaces to the right of -48 so the answer is 18.<------(-48)--------------------(-30)----------------->Using this method of calculation, the Modulo function in Python will always return a positive integer between 0 and B-1

column8: For information purposes only, and not to comment for or against any post above. Negative indices can be thought of as if you were shifting the index to the left from the first element, and rotating counter-clockwise through the last element. This can therefore be thought of as a pointer, and not math. I can only guess that the reason that these problems say that math should not be used is that they do not want any calculations performed such as using the len() function to in any way determine the pointer value. The idea is to teach how to access a list in this manner using only a pointer, whether it be positive or negative. The other idea here also may be to indicate the simplicity in which the element may be accessed. It may be true in some real applications that math may be required to access the desired element.

column8: One thing to remember with While loops is that any variables that are in the condition must be set before executing the While instruction the first time. If the condition is False upon the first execution, then the body of the While instruction will never be run. If it is True, then it will be run, and the the While condition will be checked again.Here is an example where you will see that you have to initialize the variable 'val'. It will enter the While loop in the first check, and the body of the While loop will be processed. It will then loop back on the While until the the condition val < 5 is true. Not that it will not enter the body of the While when val = 5. The value of five will actually be printed outside the loop.list = [1,2,3,4,5]index = 0val = list[index]while val < 5:ï_ï_ï_ print (val)ï_ï_ï_ index = index + 1ï_ï_ï_ val = list[index]print ("End loop")print (val)Here is another example where it will never enter the body of the While loop. The initial value of val will be '5'. When val is checked on the first conditional check it will equate to False. Execution will then continue at the instruction that prints "End Loop".list = [1,2,3,4,5]index = len(list)-1val = list[index]while val < 5:ï_ï_ï_ print (val)ï_ï_ï_ index = index + 1ï_ï_ï_ val = list[index]print ("End loop")print (val)

column8: As Etienne said, the idea is function reuse. When someone define a function that does some job, donïŠt repeat that code in some other place, just call the function. In this case they provide two functions, count_vowels and count_consonants. Using this two functions you must write one statements that returns the number of letters of the word.Apparently, in this case using the functions provided or the built-in function len seems to be the same, but in another scenario, for example, count_letters_in_a_var_name it could be not the same.If you want to count 'letters' in this case, the function len could not be appropiated, try this:>>>ï_len("ab4t5")Check the response and compare with the number of letters in the 'word' (just 3). This is a valid variable name, but has 3 letters and 2 numbers. While len will tell you that there's 5 letters, using count_vowels and count_consonants will take you to the correct answer.I hope that this helps.

By default, apparently there's no way to clear screen.There's an open source project that extends IDLE functionalities called Idlex. You can check it here http://idlex.sourceforge.net/features.htmlIt's a zip file that you must decompress in any folder.You can install it or run it directly (instructions for installation are in a file in the zip called Readme.txt).To run it in windows you must just double click idlex.py, on linux you must open a terminal, change into the idlex directory and run:ï_ ï_ ï_ ï_ $ python idlex.pyOnce in IDLEX (which looks just like IDLE but with all the features described in the home page), you can clear the screen pressing ctrl-lMay be you should give it a try.

'E'

Try the following:road = 'road.txt'file = open(road, 'r')line = file.readline()while line:ï_ï_ï_ print(line)ï_ï_ï_ line = file.readline()

Any object can be tested for truth value. There are some special values that are considered False, and all the rest are considered True.See this link to check all the cases that are evaluated as False:ï_http://docs.python.org/3.2/library/stdtypes.html#truth-value-testingWhen you are going through the lines of a file, the variable always have a value that evaluates to True. When the EOF (end of file)ï_is reached, the method readline returns an empty string ('') and this is one of the cases that evaluates to False.That's whyï_While line:works. line is always evaluated asï_true until the EOF.I hope it was clear.

column8:
Let's define the function first, and then call it more than once with diferent lists.Try it like this in IDLE (you can have problems with indentation during copy/paste, if it's happened, correct them):>>> def write_to_file(file, sentences):
	""" (file open for writing, list of str) -> NoneType
	Write each sentence from sentences to file, one per line.
	Precondition: the sentences contain no newlines.ï_ï_ï_ """
	for s in sentences:
		file.write(s)
		file.write('n')

		
>>> filename = 'c:lecture_code.txt'
>>> file = open(filename, 'a')
>>> sentences = ['I wanna be', 'I have to go', 'Would you like?']
>>> write_to_file(file,sentences)
>>> file.close()
>>> moreWords = ['More', 'Words', 'To', 'Add']
>>> file = open(filename, 'a')
>>> write_to_file(file,moreWords)
>>> file.close()
>>> This is working for me and this is the content of the result file:I wanna beI have to goWould you like?MoreWordsToAdd

But, I am wondering if we could actually do and practice higher(University) level Math using programming alone? I mean to actually study Math via programming(instead of writing it down on a paper). In that way one can improve Math and coding skills at the same time.ï_I suppose I could also ask a similar question for learning Physics?Thank you.ï_VJ.

I know that we need some knowledge of Math to do programming(Math is a path to programming). But can I actually study higher level Math using programming, that is my question? In other words, can Programming(as a tool) be a path to Math?

Hey Alan, Thank you take your time to post a detailed view. I am not that young. I am 30. I am actually doing my PhD in Molecular Biology, but all I do there is physical work. There is no real thought process involved, let alone use of imagination. I am not very satisfied with my work. I have always been fond of Math and Physics(wanted to study them since school), but due to circumstances I chose to do Medicine and continuing now with a PhD. I am in a transition stage right now. I started studying Math on my own and attending few online courses as well. Hence my question about programming and Math, as I am relatively new to this area. I am actually finding myself more and more involved. I might as well discontinue my PhD and start full time with Math and Physics. I haven't made the decision and I am doing all this on my free-time. I just finished revising all my school Math and going to start with University level Math.ï_In this whole thread, I seem to find that I actually cannot use programming as the only tool to study Math and Physics, rather there are some places, where I can use the power of programming to execute my problems in a much efficient way. For example, in the coursera course: Introductory Physics, we used python to understand Newton's 2nd law, it was way better than doing all of that using paper and pen. Hence I opted for this course in programming. Now I am trying to figure out to what extent programming can actually help me understand Math and Physics.ï_I observe that to have a conceptual understanding of Math and Physics, I must study them as they are.ï_To state a real example, I actually understood boolean logical operators('and' 'or' 'if statements', which I am studying in Intro to Math thinking) better after joining this course.ï_ï_Hence I was wondering if programming could actually help me learn Math and what are the ways that I could use programming to learn Math. Any suggestions are welcome. :) :) :)ï_

Hello all,I had asked similar question in calculus one course forum, they've given me information about ï_Project Eulerï_and Sage. They also agreed with the fact that I can indeed use programming as a platform to study maths. Though I feel at the beginning one needs to know both programming and some level of Math to begin with, that means I might not be able to use programming as a stand-alone platform, rather as an additional(a very good additional) platform. Especiallyï_Project Euler, seems to be exciting, as it tries to combine programming and mathematical problems to get deeper insights. In addition, to the amazing links given in this forum, I think I now have a pretty good overview and decent information to start working on it.ï_And some more: Mathematicaï_seems to be cool as well, Book:ï_ï_"Calculus&Mathematica",ï_by Davis, Porta, UhlAnother brief example: I have also been doing Intro to Math. Philosophy course and they were using ï_not(p) or q
quite often and I never was able to understand it. After Alain's example above on Implication statement, I actually seem to understand it better.
